Triggering Event:
Scenario:
A sudden power outage at midnight. The old artist, startled awake in his dimly lit studio apartment, fears for his partner in the next room. He can't hear her breathing over the distant howl of a storm, triggering an irrational fear that she's been taken by the darkness.
Generated Assessment: *This is a reflection of my inner self.* As I lay here, listening to the thunder, I feel like I'm either completely okay with what's happening or completely out of control. It feels like there are no other options in between - everything is black and white. If it's just a power outage, then everything will be fine; if I don't hear her breathing, she must have been taken by something supernatural. There's no middle ground, and this all-or-nothing thinking is making me more anxious than necessary. It's as if my mind is forcing me to choose one extreme side of the spectrum, leaving me feeling trapped between two opposing emotions. In reality, maybe it's just a minor technical issue, but *this thought makes me think it could be anything from a simple power outage to some kind of attack*. I know intellectually that it's probably neither, but somehow, my brain refuses to accept that ambiguity. The fear of the unknown has me torn between two extremes: either I'll find out it's nothing, or it'll be much worse than I imagine. Either way, I'll end up feeling helpless. This all-or-nothing thinking is making things seem more intense than they actually are, and I'm not sure how to break free from it.

Triggering Event: "Upon opening the store, he found a pile of unsold, outdated stock pushed to his section's entrance, a stark reminder of his dwindling sales. The manager had left a note: 'Turn this around by end of month or discuss consequences.' He felt the familiar heat of shame creep up his neck as he began his shift alone."
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, I'm so fucking done with all these fucking stores! They're always piling shit at my feet like it's some kind of sick joke. If you can't even be bothered to get rid of that old crap, why are we supposed to sell it? It's just another way of saying I don't give a fuck about me. This is what happens when you hire people who have no idea how to run a business. And now they're making me work twice as hard because I have to clean up after them? Are they kidding me?!" "I swear, every time I walk through those doors, I feel like I'm walking into a nightmare. It's like they want me to fail. But what really gets under my skin is when they say things like, ‘Just turn this around by the end of the month, or...’ Like, are they serious? Do they think I’m going to magically make it rain sales out of thin air? Newsflash: you guys are not my parents. You’re not there to babysit me; you expect results. And if I don’t deliver, well, maybe then I’ll understand why I got hired in the first place.” "It’s just so fucking infuriating. I mean, come on, if they couldn’t care enough to get rid of that shit, why would they trust me to handle anything else? It’s like they’re playing a cruel joke on us, watching us struggle while they sit back

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

The woman, her hands trembling slightly from the weight of her years and the pressure of her deadline, watched as the printer sputtered out the final page of her article at 11:58 PM. She had stayed late, long after the office had emptied, to finish her piece on the city's latest corruption scandal. As she reached for the printout, the phone rang - an unfamiliar number flashing on the caller ID. She hesitated, then picked up, feeling a familiar tension knot in her shoulders as she braced herself for yet another late-night source who'd changed their mind about going on record.
Generated Assessment: You know how some people always seem to have it all together? Like they're just effortlessly handling life one thing at a time? That's what I get when I think of my mom. She was this amazing, organized person who seemed to have everything under control. But now that I'm older, I realize she wasn't really like that. In fact, she often struggled with stress, especially during those late-night moments. When I look back, I can see that she was actually pretty frazzled a lot of the time. Like remember that time she spent hours working on a story, trying to meet a tight deadline? Or how about when she got so stressed out over getting everything done that she ended up staying late, sometimes even into the night? It makes me wonder if maybe she felt overwhelmed by the pressure to perform. Maybe she didn't feel as put together as she thought she did. It's funny how our minds can distort things like that. Sometimes we focus too much on the negative, making it seem like things were way worse than they actually were. Anyway, I guess I've learned a little bit more about my mom lately, and I appreciate seeing things from a different perspective.

Maybe she wants to hurt us!** *The thought sends shivers down her spine.* **Okay, okay, let’s say he’s homeless. That means he must be desperate. But maybe he’s not desperate enough to harm us.** *She tries to justify everything.* **Hmph! Well, I

Triggering Event: While sorting through old boxes in her cluttered garage, she stumbled upon their wedding album, forgotten and dusty. Each page was a stark reminder of happier times, now reduced to faded photographs and bittersweet memories.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, why did I find this?! It's like time stopped right there. I can't believe I forgot about him. How could I? He would never forget me. We were meant for each other. The way he looked at me, the way I felt when we hugged, the way he held my hand... all gone. He is probably thinking about me too. He must miss me terribly. If only he knew how much I missed him. Why did things have to end like this? I feel as if I'm drowning in sadness. It's like the whole world has come crashing down around me. Everything feels hollow and empty. Every step I take, every breath I make, just reminds me of him. My heart is heavy with grief, and I can't stop crying. How could he leave me like this? What happened to us? Where did our love go? Why did we let each other go? Did we even deserve to begin with? Was everything I gave him enough? Shouldn't he remember me fondly? Does he think I've forgotten about him? What does the future hold for me now? Is it more pain and sorrow? Will I ever see him again? Or am I doomed to live forever in this darkness? Can I really move on from this? How can I forgive myself for letting him go? Am I responsible for ending our relationship? Was I somehow to blame? Did I push him away? Did I scare him off

Triggering Event: A colleague, with whom he had once shared a byline, casually mentioned during a lunch break, "You used to be able to handle more than this, didn't you?" while glancing at his half-empty notebook.
Generated Assessment: It's quite unfortunate that the opportunity to share our work together was lost when I retired from academia. I've been keeping busy since then, but it's not as fulfilling as I'd hoped. This past weekend, we were discussing how many hours are spent writing for a journal, and I mentioned my experience working for 6 years before retirement. My colleagues seemed surprised, especially after I mentioned that I had co-authored several papers, including one published in a reputable journal. When they asked about my current projects, I realized that they hadn't considered the possibility that I might still be involved in research despite not being actively employed. I can't help but feel a bit frustrated that people often seem to believe that I'm no longer interested in academic pursuits. Perhaps I could have made more time for them if I weren't so focused on finding new ways to contribute to the field. While I appreciate their interest, I wish they would consider alternative possibilities, such as the fact that I might be exploring different avenues for engagement. The idea that I've simply given up is unpalatable, even though I understand that my personal choices don't necessarily define my commitment to the field.

Triggering Event: A regular at his restaurant, a elderly woman with a warm smile and wrinkles etched by laughter, approached him as he wiped down the counter after closing. She handed him an envelope, saying, "I always leave something for you, but this time... I couldn't help noticing how much weight you've lost." Her eyes held a kindness that felt like pity, making his stomach churn with shame. He watched her walk away, leaving behind the usual generous tip and a silent accusation he couldn't shake off.
Generated Assessment: It was so weird when she said that. I know she's trying to be kind, but it feels really personal. I mean, why would anyone notice my weight loss? Is she even paying attention to me or is it just about being nice? What if she didn’t even notice? Maybe she thinks everyone loses weight? I don’t see why she has to say anything anyway. It’s not like she knows what I’ve been through. But then again, maybe she does care? That’s probably why she mentioned it. I guess she’s concerned about me or something. Maybe she doesn’t think twice about it, but still wants to make sure I’m okay. Like, who wouldn’t want to help someone struggling? Why did she have to mention it though? Can’t she just be nice without bringing up sensitive stuff? She must have seen me looking tired lately. I guess she noticed because she cares. But why bring it up now? I should just ignore it and keep smiling. Everyone gets old sometimes, right? It’s probably just my imagination. What if she wasn’t thinking about me at all? Maybe she’s just friendly with everyone. Triggering Event:
Scenario:
After another grueling 12-hour shift, she rushed home, eager to relax. As she opened her front door, she was greeted by a mountain of dishes in the sink and an unmade bed - remnants of her roommate's weekend binge. She felt a familiar tension knot in her shoulders as she realized there'd be no peace tonight. Just another thing on her endless to-do list.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, this is going to be one of those nights, isn't it? The dishes are piling up, and my roommate is still sleeping off her latest bender. It's like they're trying to make me feel guilty about everything else I've been stressing over lately. I can already imagine how exhausting tomorrow will be - cleaning up after them, dealing with their messes... It feels like the universe just wants to throw more problems at me when I'm already running on fumes. I wish I could just tell myself to take a deep breath and let go, but I know it won't work. Tonight is just going to keep getting worse, and I'll have to face all these responsibilities again tomorrow morning. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She's been at the restaurant since 6 AM, prepping for tonight's rush. Her partner texted hours ago, "We need to talk." Those three words have been echoing in her mind all day. Now, as she chops onions, her hands tremble slightly. The kitchen staff notices but says nothing. The clock ticks closer to service time. She tries to focus on the task, but her anxiety grows with each tick, her breath shallow, chest tight. Another text: "Can't wait any longer. I'm coming by after my shift." Her heart pounds. What if this is it? What if he's had enough of her late nights and endless stress? She drops the knife, wiping her hands on her apron before lighting a cigarette outside, taking deep drags to calm herself. The bell rings; they're open.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe she's being so dramatic about her partner leaving her. It's just another bad decision. He always does that. He never follows through. And now, because of him, she's stressing over every little thing. She needs to chill out and get her priorities straight. If anything, she's overreacting. I mean, we've seen her come back late many times, but this time, it feels different. She's probably just anxious about work. That's what happens when you're working long hours and dealing with difficult customers. She'll get over it. Maybe this whole situation will blow over like everything else. What's really surprising is how quickly she's taken to smoking again. It's almost like she's trying to distract herself from her problems. But let's be real, it won't help. We've all seen her smoke throughout her shifts. This isn't a new behavior. There's no reason to assume it's related to her current situation. It's probably just a nervous habit. Besides, she can quit anytime she wants. She doesn't need us telling her that. We're here to support her, not lecture her. The worst part is that she's still acting like an idiot, constantly making mistakes and getting flustered during service. I swear, she must be stressed about something more than just her relationship issues. She's usually better than this. But then again, maybe she's just having a rough night. Maybe it's nothing
